fdd:description.p: Operational Pattern (OP) for a file with a tightly defined structure for a single item of essence described by a single essence track. OP-Atom is designed for applications where each essence track is held separately. According to an Avid promotional booklet, OP-Atom files are "applicable to content authoring steps such as non-linear editing, where programs are created by slicing and dicing different sections of source material." This contrasts with the OP preferred for "applications where each file represents a complete program or take," e.g., MXF_OP1a. An explanatory paper from MOG Solutions in 2007 stated that if "you want to keep the picture and sound information separately . . . OP-Atom is the way to go. And you will then gradually improve the linkage between the different assets by using mechanisms in MXF Structural Metadata that enable you to link the OP-Atom files together." OP-Atom files are output by some digital video cameras.

fdd:adoption.p: OP-Atom is supported in Avid systems. MXF in an OP-Atom mode is part of the ensemble of specifications associated with the Digital Cinema Initiative; see DCDM, DCP, and MXF_DCI. Panasonic P2 digital video cameras can output MXF OP-Atom files with DVC Pro encodings (see DV-DIF).
